title: Information Science
subtitle: A quick overview of important courses from my bachelor

questions.label: Web Programming
questions.content: Developped interactive websites using PHP, JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. It covered jQuery, AJAX, JSON, and templating for efficient web development. Also worked with virtual Apache servers, FTP, and software development tools. Through weekly assignments and a group project, we applied theoretical knowledge to real-world problems. The course emphasized collaboration, software development best practices, and the ability to propose, reflect on, and present web applications in a scientific manner.

questions.label: Text manipulation
questions.content: Learned to work with Linux/Unix for text manipulation, including editing, searching with regular expressions, creating glossaries and frequency lists, and using Unix pipes to connect commands like grep, cat, cut, and sed. The course covers electronic text processing, focusing on searching, replacing, sorting, and text analysis applications.

questions.label: Annotation for Machine Learning
questions.content: Learned to define annotation goals, collect datasets, create annotation models, evaluate annotations, and build gold standard corpora for Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasks. I performed statistical analysis, trained ML models using annotated features, evaluated their performance, and developed strong baseline models. Through hands-on experience, I understood how annotation improves machine learning in NLP and how to build high-quality annotated datasets.

questions.label: Project Text Analysis
questions.content: Introduced to processing large textual datasets using Python and the NLTK library. It covers fundamental language processing tasks, including tokenization, Part of Speech (POS)-tagging, Named Entity Recognition (NER), and sense-tagging, both theoretically and practically. Learned to implement these techniques, evaluate data annotation, and set up NLP projects from scratch. Practical assignments reinforce classroom learning, culminating in a group project where students develop an NLP system using off-the-shelf tools. Additionally, the course fosters teamwork skills and awareness of current challenges in text processing.

questions.label: Digital Communication
questions.content: An introduction to computer-mediated communication (CMC), covering instant messaging, video chat, email, social media, and virtual reality. Students will develop basic knowledge and analytical skills to understand the cognitive, linguistic, and social aspects of CMC, including its possibilities, limitations, and implications. A key focus is how different media influence interaction compared to face-to-face communication, exploring why certain media suit specific interactions better and how they address miscommunication. The course also examines language change, highlighting how CMC fosters new linguistic and communicative conventions, serving as preparation for advanced studies in CIW and IK.

questions.label: Introduction to Neural Networks
questions.content: Gained a foundational understanding of neural networks (NNs), covering simple linear classifiers, feed-forward neural networks, and recurrent NNs. Learned how these models work and the basic training techniques, such as stochastic gradient descent. Also gained practical experience implementing, training, and testing NN models using Python-based deep learning frameworks like Keras or PyTorch. The course highlights the conceptual differences between simple models and more advanced architectures like LSTMs, and teaches students to select appropriate NN models for text classification tasks. Additionally, students will evaluate the advantages and limitations of using deep learning compared to other machine learning methods in natural language processing.

questions.label: Search Engines
questions.content: This module covers methods and techniques used in information systems, particularly for unstructured text, such as search engines and information retrieval systems. Topics include text preparation, indexing, boolean and vector models, ranked retrieval, evaluation of search systems, and the PageRank algorithm. Students will gain hands-on experience through Python programming exercises, focusing on optimizing the efficiency of these systems when working with large data collections. Additionally, they will learn about search engine models, their internal structures, and processes, as well as how to evaluate search engine performance.

questions.label: Databases
questions.content: Database design, management, and analysis. Gained knowledge of digital data storage, data treatment, and analysis techniques. They will learn to design and implement relational databases using the E-R Model and SQL for data manipulation and queries. The course also covers database design theory, including functional dependencies and normalization. Additionally, students will be introduced to non-relational databases (NoSQL). The practical approach of the course equips students with the skills to work with databases and use contemporary tools for efficient data management.

questions.label: Conversational Interfaces
questions.content: The development and evaluation of conversational interfaces, such as chatbots, spoken dialogue systems, and talking robots. Students will explore state-of-the-art techniques in human-machine conversation, learning to handle typed or spoken input, manage dialogue, and generate appropriate responses. The course emphasizes the use of language technology to create effective and efficient conversational systems. By the end, students will be able to characterize and apply current methods in the design and evaluation of these interfaces.

questions.label: Database-driven webtechnology
questions.content: How to develop interactive server-side web applications with a relational database back end, using PHP, MySQL, and HTML. Students will gain practical experience designing relational databases for real-world applications and understanding the underlying mechanisms of web-based applications. The course also covers security, privacy, performance, usability, and best practices in software development. Through individual and group assignments, students will develop a CRUD web application with user management, addressing a real-world problem. Additionally, they will learn about version control, MVC, and APIs while working collaboratively and reflecting on the development process.

questions.label: Logic programming
questions.content: Prolog, a logic programming language. Learned basic terminology, data structures, and key techniques like unification, recursion, and backtracking. They will gain the skills to analyze and verify simple Prolog programs and develop small programs to solve non-trivial problems, such as logic puzzles. The course emphasizes declarative programming, where instead of telling the computer what to do, students describe a set of facts and rules from which the computer can derive new conclusions. Practical exercises help reinforce the theoretical concepts.

questions.label: What do you enjoy most about this work?
questions.content: I love learning new things and being able to create just about anything from scratch, creating beautiful things that people will use and appreciate.

questions.label: Hobbies outside of work?
questions.content: I love what I do, so I usually spend a lot of time working on personal projects, photography, etc. I'm also a big sports fan. I often go to the gym and I recently started climbing!
